properties.TITLE: Boil Water Notice - Waterford
properties.DESCRIPTION:
This Notice does not apply to the whole water supply. Only properties which have been individually provided with a copy of this notice are affected.

Following a technical review of the Ballycurrane water treatment plant it has been determined that the mains water supply to the properties in the affected area has not received adequate contact time to guarantee the drinking water has been fully disinfected.Â 

Irish Water and Waterford City & County Council have consulted with the Health Service Executive in relation to this matter. Following this consultation, we are issuing the following Advisory Notice with immediate effect to protect the health of the affected consumers.

Please undertake either of the following options to render your water safe to drink:

1. Allow any water drawn from the kitchen tap to be used for drinking, brushing teeth, making ice, or washing foods which will be eaten without further cooking (e.g. salad vegetables, fruit, etc.) to stand in a clean container (e.g. a jug, pot, kettle, bottle etc.) for at least 30 minutes before drinking or other use.

Alternatively

2. Boil and cool any water to be used for drinking, brushing teeth, making ice, or washing foods which will be eaten without further cooking (e.g. salad vegetables, fruit, etc.)

This advisory notice only applies to a limited number of properties supplied from the Ballycurrane water treatment plant supply.Â 

All consumers affected by this notice must either allow water to stand for 30 minutes or alternatively boil and cool their water before drinking.

Areas Affected: All customers in receipt of this notice.

1: If boiling your water ensure it is rolling boiled for 1 minute and then cooled for:

â¢Drinking
â¢Preparing Drinks made with water
â¢Preparation of salads and similar foods, which are not cooked prior to eating
â¢Brushing of teeth and/or gargling
â¢Making of ice. However, ensure you first discard all existing ice cubes in fridges and freezers and filtered water in fridges

IMPORTANT: Boil water by bringing to a vigorous, rolling boil and allow to cool. Cover and store in a refrigerator or cold place. Water from the hot tap of kitchen or bathroom sinks is not safe to drink.

2: You do not have to allow water to stand for 30 minutes or boil and cool your water for the following:

â¢Personal hygiene, baths and showersÂ 
â¢Flushing of toilets
â¢Watering plants and flowers

3: Caution:

â¢Domestic water filters will not render water safe to drink
â¢Caution should be taken when bathing children to ensure that they do not swallow the bathing water

All consumers affected by this notice must either allow water to stand for 30 minutes or alternatively boil and cool their water before drinking.

1:Â If boiling your water ensure it is rolling boiled for 1 minute and then cooled for:

â¢Drinking
â¢Preparing Drinks made with water
â¢Preparation of salads and similar foods, which are not cooked prior to eating
â¢Brushing of teeth and/or gargling
â¢Making of ice. However, ensure you first discard all existing ice cubes in fridges and freezers and filtered water in fridges

properties.TITLE: Boil Water Notice - Waterford
properties.DESCRIPTION:

Please undertake either of the following options to render your water safe to drink:

1.Â Allow any water drawn from the kitchen tap to be used for drinking, brushing teeth, making ice, or washing foods which will be eaten without further cooking (e.g. salad vegetables, fruit, etc.) to stand in a clean container (e.g. a jug, pot, kettle, bottle etc.) for at least 30 minutes before drinking or other use.

2.Â Boil and cool any water to be used for drinking, brushing teeth, making ice, or washing foods which will be eaten without further cooking (e.g. salad vegetables, fruit, etc.)

This advisory notice only applies to a limited number of properties supplied from the Kilmore-Kilbeg Water Treatment Plant.

All consumers affected by this notice must either allow water to stand for 30 minutes or alternatively boil and cool their water before drinking.

1:Â If boiling your water ensure it is rolling boiled for 1 minute and then cooled for:

â¢Preparing Drinks made with water
â¢Preparation of salads and similar foods, which are not cooked prior to eating
â¢Brushing of teeth and/or gargling
â¢Making of ice. However, ensure you first discard all existing ice cubes in fridges and freezers and filtered water in fridges

IMPORTANT:Â Boil water by bringing to a vigorous, rolling boil and allow to cool. Cover and store in a refrigerator or cold place. Water from the hot tap of kitchen or bathroom sinks is not safe to drink.

2:Â You do not have to allow water to stand for 30 minutes or boil and cool your water for the following:

â¢Personal hygiene, baths and showersÂ 
â¢Flushing of toilets
â¢Watering plants and flowers

This Notice will remain in place until we can take the necessary actions to remove this risk from your water supply. We currently expect the works to upgrade the treatment process to remove the risk from your water supply will be completed by mid-2019. IMPORTANT: Boil water by bringing to a vigorous, rolling boil and allow to cool. Cover and store in a refrigerator or cold place. Water from the hot tap of kitchen or bathroom sinks is not safe to drink.

2: You do not have to allow water to stand for 30 minutes or boil and cool your water for the following:

â¢Caution should be taken when bathing children to ensure that they do not swallow the bathing water

4: Only use Prepared Water (i.e. that has been allowed to stand for 30 minutes - or boiled and cooled beforehand) for the following situations.

properties.TITLE: Boil Water Notice - Sligo
properties.DESCRIPTION:
Â **Update 21/01/2019**

Irish Water and Sligo County Council wishes to notify all customers on the Bellahy DMA previously served by the Lough Talt Regional Water Supply Scheme that the boil water notice imposed in this area on the 11th of January 2019, is now lifted with immediate effect as the scheme is now supplied from the Charlestown Public Water Supply Scheme.

This notice applies to 435 consumers supplied in Bellaghy, Sandyhill, Cloonaughill, Cully, the southern 80% part of Bunnacrannagh, Brackloonagh, Brogher, Lissard, and Curryfuel and as indicated on the map.Â 

Please note that the consumers that are not on the Bellahy DMA, remain on the Boil Water Notice until further notice.

It has come to the attention of Irish Water and Sligo County Council that the water supply served by the Lough Talt Public Water Supply is contaminated with cryptosporidium. Following consultation with the Health Service Executive, Irish Water and Sligo County Council are issuing a Boil Water Notice with immediate effect to protect the health of consumers.

This notice applies to all consumers on the Lough Talt Public Water Supply and consumers on the Ogham water scheme which is served from the Lough Talt supply.

**All customers must boil their water before drinking.**

All persons served by the Lough Talt Public Water Supply and the Ogham group water scheme.

This includes for the following areas in County Sligo; Curry, Killoran, Carrowcushely, Glenn-Kinnagrelly, Carrownacarrick, Kilmacteige, Achonry, Talt-Castleoye Trunk, Aclare, Tobercurry, Kesh, Achonry-Ballymote Trunk, Moylough, Templehouse, Ballymote, Muckelty, Rockfield, Annagh, Oldrock, Cloonacool, Quaryfield, Banada, Killavel, Branchfield and Collooney.

This notice also applies to the following areas in County Mayo; Cloontia, QuarryField and Doocastle.

Actions to be undertaken by all consumers on this BWN.

1. Water must be boiled for:
- Drinking
- Drinks made with water
- Preparation of salads and similar foods, which are not cooked prior to eating
- Brushing of teeth
- Making of ice
Â - Discard ice cubes in fridges and freezers and filtered water in fridges. Make ice from cooled boiled water.

2. Use water prepared for drinking when preparing foods that will not be cooked (e.g. washing salads).

3. Water can be used for personal hygiene, bathing and flushing of toilets but not for brushing teeth or gargling.

4. Boil water by bringing to a vigorous, rolling boil (e.g. with an automatic kettle) and allow to cool. Cover and store in a refrigerator or cold place. Water from the hot tap is not safe to drink. Domestic water filters will not render water safe to drink.

5. Caution should be taken when bathing children to ensure that they do not swallow the bathing water.

6. Where a Boil Water Notice is in place, you can prepare infant formula from tap water that has been boiled once (rolling boil for 1 minute) and cooled beforehand. Bottled water can also be used to make up infant formula. All bottled water, with the exception of natural mineral water, is regulated to the same standard as drinking water. It is best not to use bottled water labelled as âNatural Mineral Waterâ as it can have high levels of sodium (salt) and other minerals, although it rarely does. âNatural Mineral Waterâ can be used if no other water is available, for as short a time as possible, as it is important to keep babies hydrated. If bottled water is used to make up infant formula it should be boiled once (rolling boil for 1 minute), and cooled in the normal way. Ready-to-use formula that does not need added water can also be used.

7. Anyone suffering from diarrhoea for more than two days should contact their general practitioner and provide a stool sample for testing. They should continue to drink plenty of boiled or bottled water.

Great care should be taken with boiled water to avoid burns and scalds as accidents can easily happen, especially with children.

What is Cryptosporidium?

Cryptosporidium is a microscopic parasite that is found mainly in the faeces of infected humans or animals.Humans are infected when they swallow contaminated water or food, or touch contaminated objects and then touch their mouths before washing their hands well.

What are the symptoms?

Diarrhoea that lasts 1 to 2 weeks, often accompanied by abdominal cramps, tiredness, nausea, vomiting and low grade fever. People usually develop symptoms 1 to 12 days after swallowing the parasite. If you are worried contact your GP.

What can I do to prevent getting it?

Use boiled water for:
- Drinking
- Drinks made with water
- Preparation of salads and similar foods, which are not cooked prior to eating
- Brushing of teeth
- Making ice

Wash your hands carefully after going to the toilet, changing nappies, and before preparing food.

Be careful when bathing small children to ensure that they do not swallow any bath water.

As Cryptosporidium can be passed from animals to humans, ensure that you and your children always wash your hands after handling any animals (including pets) or after visiting a farm.

Do not drink unpasteurised milk.

Who is most at risk?

Persons with an impaired immune system, young children and older people are most at risk of picking up Cryptosporidium.

How long before the boil water notice can be lifted?

We do not know at present, but Irish Water will continue to liaise with the Health Service Executive with a view to lifting the Boil Water Notice as soon as practicable.

8. How will we keep you informed?

You will be kept informed through the following media:

Website: www.water.ie; www.sligococo.ie

Irish Water Customer Contact Centre: 1890 278 278

Local Media âOcean FM, Sligo Champion and Sligo Weekender.

(IW registered vulnerable customers will be directly contacted)

9. Awareness for commercial premises:

Irish water request that this Boil Water Notice is placed in a prominent position within your
commercial premises

Remember to boil water as advised until further notice.

properties.TITLE: Do Not Consume Notice - Wicklow
properties.DESCRIPTION:
Following consultation with the Health Service Executive (HSE), Irish Water working in partnership with Wicklow County Council issued a Do Not Consume Notice for all 269 customers on the Kiltegan Water Supply Scheme. This is due to elevated levels of nitrate in the water supply.

It is especially important that mains drinking water is not given to bottle fed infants.

Please note this is not a Boil Water Notice. Boiling the water will not reduce nitrate levels and is therefore not a suitable measure to make the water safe to consume. This notice does not apply to any other areas or water schemes in County Wicklow.

Irish Water is providing bottled water which is available from 9am to 7pm MondayÂ to Friday andÂ 9am to 5pm on weekends, beside Katie Lowes Pub.

Irish Waterâs drinking water compliance and operational experts are working with colleagues in the Wicklow County Council to resolve this situation as soon as possible. Irish Water is progressing with plans to drill a new borehole to provide a new water source that will resolve this issue permanently. This is scheduled to be completed in early 2019.

Public Health Advice:

â¢Â  This water should not be used for:
â¢Â Â  Drinking
â¢Â Â  Drinks made with water
â¢Â Â  Good preparation, washing or cooking of food,
â¢Â Â  Brushing of teeth
â¢Â Â  Making of ice

â¢Â  In particular, children under 12 months old should not drink this water.
â¢Â  This water should not be used for making up infant formula for bottled fed infants. An alternative source of water should be used. Bottled water can also be used to make up infant formula. All bottled water, with the exception of natural mineral water, is regulated to the same standard as drinking water. It is best not to use bottled water labelled as âNatural Mineral Waterâ as it can have high levels of sodium (salt) and other minerals, although it rarely does. âNatural Mineral Waterâ can be used if no other water is available, for as short a time as possible, as it is important to keep babies hydrated.
â¢Â Â  If bottled water is used to make up infant formula it should be boiled once (rolling boil for 1 minute), and cooled in the normal way.
â¢Â Â  Ready-to-use formula that does not need added water can also be used.
â¢Â Â  Domestic water filters will not render water safe to drink.
â¢Â Â  Caution should be taken when bathing infants to ensure that they do not swallow the bathing water.
â¢Â Â  Discard ice cubes in fridges and freezers and filtered water in fridges.

What can you use mains water for:

â¢Â Â  The water can be used for personal hygiene, bathing, flushing toilets, laundry and washing of utensils.

Irish Water and Wicklow County Council will continue to liaise with the Health Service Executive with a view to lifting this drinking water restriction as soon as practicable.

properties.TITLE: Drinking Water Restriction - Cork
properties.DESCRIPTION:
On the advice of the Health Service Executive, a Do Not Use Notice is being re issued to consumers on a section of cast Iron main on the Tibbotstown Public Water Supply. Accordingly, in the interest of public health, it is recommended that all users on this section of main do not use the drinking water. The notice has been imposed due to a further exceedance in the standard level of Iron in the supply.

â¢This water should not be used forÂ 
- drinking,Â 
- drinks made with water,Â 
- food preparation, washing or cooking of food,Â 
- brushing of teeth, orÂ 
- making of ice.

â¢ In particular, pregnant women should not drink this water.

â¢This water should not be used for making up infant formula for bottled fed infants. An alternative source of water should be used. If using bottled water, the bottled water should be boiled first (to sterilise) and avoid bottled water labelled as âNatural Mineral Waterâ as it can have higher levels of sodium and other minerals. It can be used if no other water is available, for as short a time as possible, as it is important to keep babies hydrated.

â¢The water can be used for personal hygiene, bathing, flushing toilets, laundry and washing of utensils.

â¢Domestic water filters will not render water safe to drink.

â¢Caution should be taken when bathing children to ensure that they do not swallow the bathing water.

â¢Discard ice cubes in fridges and freezers and filtered water in fridges.Â 

Please note that boiling the water will not be sufficient to make it suitable to drink.Â Â 

A tankered water supply will be made available at the Retail Site between Lidl and Aldi, Ticknock, Cobh, Co. Cork from 6pm on 19 November.

How long before the Do Not Consume Notice can be lifted?
We do not know at present, but Irish Water and Cork County Council will continue to liaise with the Health Service Executive with a view to lifting the Do Not Use Notice as soon as practicable.

How will we keep you informed?Â 
â¢ Leaflet drops
â¢ Website: www.water.ieÂ 
â¢ Irish Water Customer Contact Centre: 1850 278 278.

Areas affected:
â¢ Tibbotstown Supply - Belvelly to Ticknock section ONLY.

properties.TITLE: Boil Water Notice - Galway
properties.DESCRIPTION:
It has come to the attention of Irish Water and Galway County Council that the water supply served by the Kilconnell Public Water Supply is potentially unsafe due to elevated turbidity in the raw water. As a result, and following consultation with the Health Service Executive, Irish Water and Galway County Council are issuing a Boil Water Notice with immediate effect to protect the health of consumers.

This notice only applies to consumers on the Kilconnell Public Water Supply and the Ballyboggan Group Water Scheme who must boil water before use.

1: Water must be boiled (rolling boil for 1 minute and then cooled) for:
- Drinking
- Preparing Drinks made with water
- Preparation of salads and similar foods, which are not cooked prior to eating
- Brushing of teeth and/or gargling
- Making of ice. However, ensure you first discard all existing ice cubes in fridges and freezers and filtered water in fridges

IMPORTANT: Boil water by bringing to a vigorous, rolling boil and allow to cool. Cover and store in a refrigerator or cold place. Water from the hot tap of kitchen or bathroom sinks is not safe to drink.

2: You do not have to boil your water for the following:
- Personal hygiene, baths and showers
- Flushing of toilets
- Watering plants and flowers

3: Caution:
- Domestic water filters will not render water safe to drink
- Caution should be taken when bathing children to ensure that they do not swallow the bathing water
- Discard ice cubes in fridges and freezers and filtered water in fridges. Make ice from cooled boiled water
- If you have pets and are concerned about the impact of providing mains water while this BWN is in place, you should ask your local vet for advice.

4: Only use Prepared Water (boiled and cooled) for the following situations.
- When preparing foods that will not be cooked (e.g. washing and preparing salads)
- Preparing Infant Formula. Where a Boil Water Notice is in place, you can prepare infant formula from tap water that has been boiled once (rolling boil for 1 minute) and cooled beforehand. Bottled water can also be used to make up infant formula. All bottled water, with the exception of natural mineral water, is regulated to the same standard as drinking water. It is best not to use bottled water labelled as âNatural Mineral Waterâ as it can have high levels of sodium (salt) and other minerals, although it rarely does. âNatural Mineral Waterâ can be used if no other water is available, for as short a time as possible, as it is important to keep babies hydrated. If bottled water is used to make up infant formula it should be boiled once (rolling boil for 1 minute), and cooled in the normal way. Ready-to-use formula that does not need added water can also be used.

5: Always Take Care:
- Care should be taken with boiled water to avoid burns and scalds. Accidents can easily happen, especially with children.

6: How long before the boil water notice can be lifted?
- We do not know at present, but Irish Water will continue to liaise and consult with the Health Service Executive with a view to lifting the Boil Water Notice as soon as practicable.

properties.TITLE: Low Water Pressure - Dublin
properties.DESCRIPTION:
**Update 09:01am 07/01/2019**

Works are now complete, and supply should begin to return to all affected properties.

Essential works may cause low pressure to Hibernian Terrace and surrounding areas in Chapelizod, Dublin 20.

Works are scheduled to take place from 8am until 11:45am on 6 January.

Supply may take 2-3 hours to fully return to all affected properties.

Please take note of the following reference number and enter it into the search bar should you wish to return for an update: CC031012.
